title: MAGA Keyword Screener
About
text:
This tool allows you to analyze documents for specific MAGA-targeted keywords. Upload a document, and the app will count words, characters, and occurrences of predetermined keywords.

How It Works
The analyzer extracts text from your document and searches for keywords from our predefined list. It then counts how many times each keyword appears in your document. That‚Äôs all - it‚Äôs pretty simple.
The underlying technology enabling this site is pretty cool though! It uses the Quarto publishing system, the R programming language, and the shiny web application framework, leveraging shinylive Quarto extension to run the whole thing in the browser as a static web page (thanks to @coatless for posting such a great tutorial on how to set this up). The site itself is hosted on GitHub pages, and the source code can be found here.


Supported File Types

Word Documents: .docx, .doc
PDF Files: .pdf
Text Files: .txt
Spreadsheets: .csv, .xlsx
Web Documents: .html, .htm, .xml
Other: .rtf, .json

title: Strategies
text:
If you‚Äôre frustrated / outraged by the need to censor your work, you should be. This is so, so profoundly stupid ü§¶. It‚Äôs also a rather clear violation of the 1st Amendment of the U.S. Constitution.
But look, the incompetents running these screenings aren‚Äôt doing it by hand - they‚Äôre just running documents through automated keyword searchers, just like this app. So until we have an administration that respects free speech, hopefully this tool can help you navigate working in this environment.
Once you run your document through the screener and find your matching keywords, just change them. Here are some strategies:

Use synonyms: Replace potentially flagged words with their synonyms (e.g., ‚Äúinclusive‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúwelcoming‚Äù).
Add extra letters: Insert additional letters in words that don‚Äôt change pronunciation (e.g., ‚Äúdivverse‚Äù).
Use numbers: Replace letters with numbers, e.g.¬†‚Äúo‚Äù with ‚Äú0‚Äù, capital ‚ÄúI‚Äù with ‚Äú1‚Äù.
Intentional misspellings: Slightly misspell words while keeping them recognizable (e.g., ‚Äúequaty‚Äù or ‚Äúƒïquity‚Äù using accented characters instead of ‚Äúequity‚Äù).
Add invisible characters: Insert zero-width spaces or other invisible Unicode characters between letters.
Compound splitting: Break terms into component parts with hyphens or spaces (e.g., ‚Äúsocial-justice‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúsocial fairness‚Äù).
Use circumlocution: Describe the concept rather than using the term directly.
Homophone substitution: Use words that sound the same but are spelled differently.
Use metaphors: Replace direct terms with metaphorical language that conveys similar meaning.
